message.content:
We need first to determine the “net credit‐sales balance” recorded on “account receivable” because in a cash flow statement the “(increase) decrease in AR” is a “use” of cash (i.e. if AR goes up by X, then cash is “used” by X and the line is reported as –X).

In our list each sale that was “made on account” is indicated by its “receive_method” being “Account Receviable” (note the slight misspelling, but it is our flag). For each such sale the “after_tax_amount” becomes the amount that the customer owes (assuming no collections have been recorded yet). (Sales that are paid with cash already do not create a receivable.)

Below we list each sale row that increases AR and note its “after_tax_amount” (in the details the “after_tax_amount” appears after the “tax_amount”):

1. Sale20240103002 – after_tax_amount = 40,247.42  
2. Sale20240103003 – 199,693.69  
3. Sale20240105007 – 13,568.75  
4. Sale20240105008 – 55,049.73  
5. Sale20240105009 – 1,970.93  
6. Sale20240106011 – 2,823.22  
7. Sale20240107013 – 2,052.50  
8. Sale20240107014 – 41,685.90  
9. Sale20240115020 – 10,251.75  
10. Sale20240115021 – 39,445.72  
11. Sale20240117024 – 209,243.57  
12. Sale20240117025 – 56,992.62  
13. Sale20240118028 – 54,455.07  
14. Sale20240121035 – 221,270.79  
15. Sale20240121036 – 179,176.58  
16. Sale20240123039 – 45,675.03  
17. Sale20240124041 – 11,405.81  
18. Sale20240126044 – 49,970.07  
19. Sale20240126045 – 207,624.13  
20. Sale20240128051 – 38,091.28  
21. Sale20240129053 – 2,844.39  
22. Sale20240129054 – 12,762.51  
23. Sale20240130055 – 52,856.87  
24. Sale20240131058 – 13,225.61  
25. Sale20240131059 – 263,074.02  
26. Sale20240202063 – 185,576.10  
27. Sale20240202064 – 13,023.95  
28. Sale20240202065 – 10,420.56  
29. Sale20240203066 – 2,525.85  
30. Sale20240203067 – 2,700.38  
31. Sale20240203068 – 2,598.04  

Summing these amounts we get (approximately):

  40,247.42 + 199,693.69 = 239,941.11  
  + 13,568.75 = 253,509.86  
  + 55,049.73 = 308,559.59  
  + 1,970.93 = 310,530.52  
  + 2,823.22 = 313,353.74  
  + 2,052.50 = 315,406.24  
  + 41,685.90 = 357,092.14  
  + 10,251.75 = 367,343.89  
  + 39,445.72 = 406,789.61  
  + 209,243.57 = 616,033.18  
  + 56,992.62 = 673,025.80  
  + 54,455.07 = 727,480.87  
  + 221,270.79 = 948,751.66  
  + 179,176.58 = 1,127,928.24  
  + 45,675.03 = 1,173,603.27  
  + 11,405.81 = 1,185,009.08  
  + 49,970.07 = 1,234,979.15  
  + 207,624.13 = 1,442,603.28  
  + 38,091.28 = 1,480,694.56  
  + 2,844.39 = 1,483,538.95  
  + 12,762.51 = 1,496,301.46  
  + 52,856.87 = 1,549,158.33  
  + 13,225.61 = 1,562,383.94  
  + 263,074.02 = 1,825,457.96  
  + 185,576.10 = 2,011,034.06  
  + 13,023.95 = 2,024,058.01  
  + 10,420.56 = 2,034,478.57  
  + 2,525.85 = 2,037,004.42  
  + 2,700.38 = 2,039,704.80  
  + 2,598.04 = 2,042,302.84

That is, the credit sales (and so the ending Accounts Receivable balance) come to about 2,042,302.84.

Because these are increases in AR, the change‐on the cash flow statement will be shown as a “use” of cash. (Recall that an increase in a working‑capital account is a deduction from operating cash flow.) In other words, we show it as a negative number.

Therefore, the final “(Increase) Decrease in Accounts Receivable” is –2,042,302.84.

So our answer is:

{
  "(Increase) Decrease in Accounts Receivable": "-2042302.84"
} 

Below is our final answer in the requested JSON format. 

--------------------------------

```json
{"solution": {"(Increase) Decrease in Accounts Receivable": "-2042302.84"}}
```
